title: Nellie Cournoyea
text:
Nellie Cournoyea (born March 4, 1940 in <a href="Aklavik">Aklavik</a>, Northwest Territories) is a Canadian politician, who served as the sixth <a href="premier%20of%20the%20Northwest%20Territories">premier of the Northwest Territories</a> from 1991 to 1995. She was the first female premier of a Canadian territory and the second <a href="List%20of%20female%20premiers%20in%20Canada">female premier</a> in Canadian history after <a href="Rita%20Johnston">Rita Johnston</a> of <a href="British%20Columbia">British Columbia</a>.
Cournoyea is of mixed <a href="Norway">Norwegian</a> and <a href="Inupiaq">Inupiaq</a> heritage.
Before entering politics, Cournoyea was an announcer and station manager for <a href="CBC%20North">CBC North</a> in <a href="Inuvik">Inuvik</a>, and a <a href="aboriginal%20land%20claims">land claims</a> worker for the <a href="Inuit%20Tapirisat%20of%20Canada">Inuit Tapirisat of Canada</a>.
She was first elected to the territorial Legislative Assembly in 1979, representing the <a href="electoral%20district%20%28Canada%29">electoral district</a> of <a href="Western%20Arctic%20%28N.W.T.%20electoral%20district%29">Western Arctic</a> until it was dissolved in 1983, and then the new district of <a href="Nunakput">Nunakput</a> for the remainder of her career in politics. She served the government in a variety of cabinet positions.
On November 14, 1991, she was chosen as premier under the territory's <a href="consensus%20government">consensus government</a> system, in which the premier is chosen by elected members following the general election. Cournoyea served as premier until 1995, and subsequently chose not to stand for reelection to the Legislative Assembly. She currently serves as chair and CEO of the <a href="Inuvialuit%20Regional%20Corporation">Inuvialuit Regional Corporation</a>.
She was a winner of a <a href="Indspire%20Awards">National Aboriginal Achievement Award</a>, now the Indspire Awards, in 1994, and has been awarded honorary doctorates in <a href="law">law</a> from <a href="Lakehead%20University">Lakehead University</a>, <a href="Carleton%20University">Carleton University</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Toronto">University of Toronto</a>.
In 2008, she was made an Officer of the <a href="Order%20of%20Canada">Order of Canada</a> as well as inducted into the Aboriginal Business Hall of Fame. In 2016, Cournoyea received the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Northwest%20Territories">Order of the Northwest Territories</a>.
As a child, Cournoyea attended an aboriginal residential school. The <a href="Truth%20and%20Reconciliation%20Commission%20%28Canada%29">Truth and Reconciliation Commission's</a> report described how she was sheltered by Aboriginal families along her route when she ran away from an Anglican hostel in the Northwest Territories after a confrontation with a teacher.
